journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: Development and validation of a rigid–flexible coupled dynamic valve-train model

contrib-group.aff: College of Power and Energy Engineering, Harbin Engineering University, Harbin, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: *College of Power and Energy Engineering, Harbin Engineering University, 145 Nantong Street, Harbin, 150001, People’s Republic of China. email: guojie@hrbeu.edu.cn

abstract.p: A rigid–flexible coupled dynamics model has been developed to analyse the dynamic behaviour of a pushrod valve-train system of an internal combustion engine. The elastic vibration mechanism of each flexible component is described in a floating reference frame. The mechanical impacts in a valve-train system at the opening and closing events of the valve are affected by the contact stiffness and damping of contact components. The contact force model for the cam–tappet interface was developed based on the elasto-hydrodynamic lubrication theory of finite line conjunction. The finite-difference method is used to solve the rigid–flexible coupled dynamic equations. The algorithm of finite difference and the boundary conditions have been carefully selected to solve the fourth-order Bernoulli–Euler beam equation. Experiments were conducted on a motor-driven valve-train system from a four-cylinder diesel engine. The measured valve displacement, acceleration, and contact forces showed excellent consistency with the predicted results. The rigid–flexible coupled dynamics model has shown improved accuracy compared to the lumped rigid mass system in analysing the dynamic performance of the valve-train system.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: The valve train of an internal combustion engine consists of several elastic components associated with clearances. Mechanical impacts are induced by the loss of contact between components due to existing clearances. These impacts can excite high modes of vibration of the elastic elements and lead to serious noise, wear, and possible surface damage. Compared to other components, the valve spring is the most flexible component that takes on the task of keeping components in contact with each other. The valve spring can be excited by the harmonics of the cam profile and cam shaft rotation speed, and vibrates at the natural frequency after the valve is closed [1]. The pushrod is mostly subjected to a longitudinal load, and its longitudinal vibration can affect the valve motion, especially at high speed. The rocker arm is subjected to two transverse forces at the left and right ends. The impact at the valve opening event can excite the bending vibration of the rocker arm, although its mode frequencies are relative high. The valve stem will be bearing an impact load when the valve returns to its seat. This kind of impact load can lead to serious vibration and noise because the valve seating impact is of very short duration, even though the valve motion has a kinematics constraint provided by the cam ramp profile.

Several researchers have developed dynamic valve-train models that mostly include the study of elastic vibration mechanisms in valve trains. The model introduced by Frendo et al. [2] divided the pushrod and rocker arm into two lumped masses connected with elements, accounting for stiffness and damping. In this way, the elasticity of the pushrod and rocker arm can be included in the solution of the valve-train dynamics. Iritani et al. [1] used the same method in the modelling of valve-train dynamics and divided the pushrod into a number of masses. Lee [3] regarded pushrods, rocker arms, and valve stems all as rigid bodies in a valve-train dynamic model, possibly because the effect of mode vibration in the valve trains was not of interest. Mclaughlin and Haque [4] developed a multibody simulation model of a Winston Cup valve train to study valve bounce in the ADAMS environment. It contained a flexible pushrod, a flexible rocker arm, the mass of the valve springs, and a fluctuating rocker arm ratio. Lee [5] formulated the full equations of motion of the valve train of an internal combustion engine using finite-element techniques and solved them by imposing the contact conditions.

The valve spring is a major source of compliance in valve trains and attracts researchers. Kushwaha et al. [6] introduced a multimass model to analyse the valve spring characteristics, including the spring surge effect under dynamic conditions. Frendo et al. [2] also developed a multimass spring model in which the mass nodes were connected by two series of elastic and damping elements, one for the elastodynamic characteristics and the other for the possibility of the spring coils coming into contact with each other. Based on the assumption that the possibility of the spring coils coming into contact with each other is very small in regular operation, there is no significant source of non-linearity in the valve spring, and the valve spring is usually described using linear models [7]. Pisano and Freudenstein [8] and Hanachi and Freudenstein [9] employed the wave equation to describe the displacement of the spring elements. Lee [3], Paranjpe [10], Hsu and Pisano [11], Jang and Park [12], and Rego and Martins [13] used similar methods in which the valve spring was modelled as a distributed parameter system.

The cam shaft flexibility is also a source of compliance in valve trains. Koster [14] developed a dynamic model of a flexible follower driven by a flexible shaft, in which the dynamic response was characterized merely by two dimensionless parameters, one for the follower and one for the cam shaft. Kushwaha et al. [6] studied the effect of cam shaft flexibility on valve-train dynamics. The cam shaft was modelled by two inertial point masses, connected by a three-dimensional elastic field that was represented by a stiffness and a damping matrix. Rivola et al. [15] developed a combined lumped/finite-element model of a portion of the desmodromic valve train of a racing motorbike engine. The effectiveness of the model was satisfactorily achieved. However, the cam shaft flexibility is not considered in this paper, and is left for further continued research.

Special attention has been paid to the contact force at the cam–tappet conjunction due to its high magnitude [16]. Teodorescu et al. [17] developed a friction model based on elasto-hydrodynamic lubrication theory. In this model, the friction force was assumed to be the result of a combination of boundary friction and viscous friction. The boundary friction resulted from the shearing of a very thin lubricant film, and the viscous friction force was produced by the shearing of the lubricant film. The regime of lubrication is often mixed during the cam event cycle. Similar investigations of friction models in the cam and tappet contacts can be seen in other references [12, 18–22].

The method of a lumped rigid mass system is effective, but also has its weakness. For example, the elastic vibration mechanism of a continuous body is different from a spring-damping element. In addition, the computation quality of the lumped-parameters model is sensitive to the values of stiffness and damping coefficients.

In order to understand the true dynamic characteristics of a valve-train system, a comprehensive dynamic model that can provide a more accurate prediction of valve-train motion is required. The rigid–flexible coupled dynamics used in the dynamic study of a rocket launcher [23, 24], and a robot manipulator [25–28], can be regarded as a source of reference for the dynamics simulation of valve trains. Therefore, the pushrod, rocker arm, and valve stem can all be considered to be a flexible link, namely a generalized beam with different loading conditions and different forms of elastic deflections. In this paper, the components of the valve-train system are divided into two subsystems: one is a subsystem of rigid bodies, and the other is a subsystem of generalized flexible beams. A floating reference frame is attached to the generalized beam for the consideration of elastic vibration. The dynamic model for the whole system of the valve train is obtained by considering the coupling effect between the subsystems. The dynamic model of the valve train in this method can be called a kind of rigid–flexible coupled dynamic model. It can not only analyse the elastic vibration for flexible components, but also the motion of components with very small deformations.

A solution for the elastic vibration equations can be obtained using the assumed-modes approach. The effectiveness of this method is dependent on the mode shape functions and the number of mode shapes taken into consideration. To obtain the mode shape functions is a primary step for the assumed-modes approach. This task is not easy and quick in some cases, for example, the generalized beam has a complicated boundary condition. An alternative solution for the elastic vibration equations is the finite-difference method [25, 26, 29–32]. In this paper, the finite-difference method is selected to solve the equations of the rigid–flexible coupled dynamic model.

sec.title: 2.1 Mathematical method
sec.p: A schematic representation of a generalized flexible beam is shown in Fig. 1. O–XYZ is an Earth-fixed frame, o–xyz is a floating reference frame that is attached on a specified position of the generalized flexible beam. The ox-axis is directed along the undeformed centroidal axis of the generalized beam. The relative position vector of a point, p, on the beam is r, and the relative elastic deflection vector at this point is u. Suppose the motion of the floating reference frame o–xyz is known, namely, displacement r0, velocity v0, acceleration a0, angular velocity ω0, and angular acceleration ε0.

caption.p: Dynamic system of a flexible generalized beam

In a two-dimensional problem, the generalized beam can be divided into a certain number of flexible elements. The free-body diagram for an arbitrary element at a point p in the floating reference frame o–xyz is shown in Fig. 2. The axial force, shear force, and flexural moment are described as N, Q, and M, θ represents the angle through the ox-axis to the centroidal axis of the beam.

caption.p: Dynamic condition of a flexible element

sec.title: 2.2 Valve-train model
sec.p: Figure 3 shows a schematic of a typical pushrod valve train. A rigid–flexible coupled dynamic model for a pushrod valve train in this paper is shown in Fig. 4. All the contact and separation events between different components are produced by a contact spring-damping element. The estimation method for contact parameters is shown in Appendix 2. The contact stiffness and damping coefficients are all set to zero during separation events [3, 7, 33]. The tappet, upper retainer of valve spring, and valve head are modelled as rigid bodies. The pushrod, rocker arm, valve spring, and valve stem are modelled as continuous flexible bodies. The elastic vibration mechanism for each of the four continuous components is described in a floating coordinate frame. In Fig. 4, XOY is the Earth-fixed frame, x1o1y1 is a floating reference frame that is fixed on the bottom of the pushrod with the displacement denoted as hp, u(x1, t) describes the longitudinal deflection of the pushrod with respect to its rigid body state, and θA describes the angular position of the rigid body state of the rocker arm with respect to the inertial frame XOY. The transverse deflection v(x2, t) of the rocker arm is described in the rotating frame x2o2y2 attached at the centre of the rocker arm pivot. The x2-axis is directed along the undeformed centroidal axis of the rocker arm. This also means that the x2-axis remains tangential to the centroidal axis as the rocker arm deforms. The motion of the valve spring element relative to the local reference frame x3o3y3 is described by the displacement ψ(x3, t). The longitudinal deflection w(x4, t) of the valve stem is modelled in the floating frame x4o4y4, which is fixed on the upper retainer of the valve spring.

caption.p: Schematic of a pushrod valve-train system
Rigid–flexible coupled dynamic model of the valve train

sec.p: The following assumptions are made in the development of a rigid–flexible coupled dynamic model of a valve-train system:

list-item.p: the motion of each component is assumed to be in the vertical plane (the plane of the drawing);
each flexible component can have deformation in one direction only in the vertical plane (the plane of the drawing);
each flexible component is considered to have constant cross-sectional area and uniform material properties;
the contact surfaces in the valve train are all regarded as steel-on-steel contacts. Coated or hardened treatments for the components are neglected.

The two flexible arms of the rocker arm are assumed to be Euler–Bernoulli beams, and the elastic deflection v(x2, t) of the two flexible arms can be obtained by solving the beam equation

Under engine operating condition, valve-train components perform repeated contacts and separations. There is no force applied on the rocker arm when it loses contact with the pushrod or the valve. In this paper, the boundary condition for the Euler–Bernoulli beam equation (18) is modelled as an elastic-damping support since a stiffness-damping element is introduced into the interface between any two neighbouring components, see equation (19). The elastic-damping support condition will become a free boundary condition during the separation events.
The structure around the rocker arm bore is stiffer than the left and right arms. So, the boundary condition around the rocker arm bore can be considered as a simply supported end

The valve train selected in this paper has two valve springs, an inner spring and an outer spring. Both the two springs are modelled by the above method. The force exerted by the springs on the valve, NS, is the sum of the inner spring force and the outer spring force.

In this paper, the upper retainer and clips of the valve spring are considered to be one body of mass MR. Its motion is transferred to the valve head by the valve stem, which can be regarded as an elastic link. The longitudinal deflection w(x4, t) of the valve stem can also be described by the wave equation

Therefore, the boundary condition of the valve stem can be expressed as

The finite-difference method is selected to solve the dynamics equations of the valve train, and the boundary condition is developed by introducing fictitious displacements of artificial nodes (see Appendices 2 and 3). The stability of the dynamical system model can be guaranteed as long as the convergence relationship between the interval in the time domain and the step in the spatial domain hold. The dynamic system parameters of the valve train are listed in Table 1.

sec.title: 2.3 Contact friction
sec.p: Due to the high pressure developed between the cam profile and the tappet, the lubrication at the cam and tappet interface is considered to be elasto-hydrodynamic. The friction force FCT between the cam and tappet is due to two different mechanisms, the asperity contact (boundary part, Fb) and the shear of the lubricant (hydrodynamic part, Fv) [17, 19, 21]. The boundary friction Fb is determined by the relationship proposed by Greenwood and Tripp [35] and is expressed as

where τ0 is the Eyring shear stress, and m is the pressure coefficient of the boundary shear strength. The area Aa occupied by the asperity peaks and the load Pa carried by the asperities are expressed as

where ζ is the asperity density, β is the radius of curvature, σ is the composite surface roughness parameter, AH is the Hertzian contact area, and h0 is the central oil-film thickness. An extrapolation equation for the central oil-film thickness obtained by Kushwaha et al. [6] and Teodorescu et al. [17, 36] is given as
This combines the entraining and squeeze film motion between the cam and the tappet contact surfaces. The dimensionless parameters in this equation are

where α is the pressure viscosity coefficient, η0 is the dynamic viscosity at the inlet of contact, EC is the effective elastic modulus, and RC is the instantaneous radius of curvature (see the schematic of the cam–tappet contact in Fig. 6), LC is the cam width, and ue is the oil entraining velocity, which can be determined by

where RO is the radius of the cam base circle, θC is the cam angular position, ωC is the cam angular speed with unit rad/s, and hC(θC) is the cam lift as a function of cam angular position. The cam–tappet contact parameters are listed in Table 2.
The viscous friction is given as [35]

where τ is the shear stress of the lubricant. Depending on the oil-film thickness, the lubricant may be an oil film showing Newtonian or non-Newtonian behaviour [23]. If the shear stress is lower than the Eyring shear stress τ0, Newtonian behaviour occurs, otherwise non-Newtonian behaviour occurs. Therefore, the shear stress can be expressed as
where η is the oil viscosity, η = η0 exp(αp*), uS is the sliding velocity, γ is the rate of change of shear stress with pressure, and p* is the pressure on the oil film [17]
The Hertzian contact area could be expressed according to the Hertzian formula for the contact of two cylinders as [21]
The sliding velocity between the cam and tappet is
The total friction force FCT in the cam–tappet contact can be calculated by summing the boundary friction force Fb and the viscous friction force Fv

sec.title: 3 Test Rig and Instrumentation
sec.p: A motor-driven test rig was developed using the valve-train system from a four-cylinder diesel engine after the pistons, connecting rods, crank shaft, and exhaust system were removed from the engine. A flexible shaft coupling is used to connect the cam shaft and electromotor to allow misalignment. The transducer instrumentation of the dynamic experiment of the engine valve train is shown in Figs 7 and 8.

The valve acceleration is measured with a piezo-accelerometer that is mounted on the valve head. A strain gauge bridge is attached on the bottom surface of the pushrod to record the load information of the pushrod. The load applied on the valve stem is measured with another strain gauge bridge placed on the valve stem. A shaft encoder is directly mounted on the end of the cam shaft. It can generate a cam angle marker signal with a resolution of 1° or 0.5° cam angle. The lubrication oil required in the cam–tappet contact, cam shaft bearings, and other highly loaded regions is provided by an independent oil supply device. The signals from the encoder, accelerometer, and strain gauges are collected using a data acquisition system.

sec.title: 4 Results and Discussion
sec.p: The experimental results at different cam shaft speeds were compared with the predicted results to validate the flexible coupled valve-train dynamics model. Figure 9 shows a comparison between the predicted and measured pushrod forces at 700 r/min. The predicted and measured pushrod forces are very close. Some disagreements exist, for example, the oscillation in the predicted pushrod force is not as severe as the measured force. At a higher cam shaft speed (900 r/min), the developed model still provides an acceptable prediction, as shown in Fig. 10. The magnitude of force fluctuations in both predicted and measured results increases at 900 r/min partly due to the influence of the inertial forces.

The additional mass of the piezo-accelerometer was taken into consideration in the flexible coupled valve-train dynamics model. Figure 11 shows a comparison between the predicted and measured valve acceleration at a cam shaft speed of 700 r/min. A good agreement between predicted and measured accelerations was observed. As shown in Fig. 12, the predicted valve lift agrees with the valve lift calculated by the double integration of the measured valve acceleration at a cam shaft speed of 900 r/min. The comparison between the predicted and measured valve-stem forces at a cam shaft speed of 1100 r/min also reveals good agreement (shown in Fig. 13). Valve jump and bounce were not observed in the predicted and experimental results at these relatively low speeds.

The contributions of the deflections from flexible components in the valve-train system to the total dynamic deviation are shown in Fig. 14. The contact deformation is due to the local deformation of the two contact surfaces and produces the contact force. It can be seen from Fig. 14 that the deformation of the pushrod is the major share of the total deviations in the valve-train system. This phenomenon reveals that the pushrod plays an important role in the transmission chain from cam to valve, and it is another weak connection in the valve-train system, together with the valve spring. The rocker arm contributes a secondary share of the total dynamic deviation and gets slightly ahead of the contact deformation. The influence of the valve stem on the valve motion is the smallest.

caption.p: Dynamic deviations in the valve train (1300 r/min)

sec.p: A practical dynamic model of the valve train should be able to predict the loss of contact since the components of the valve train tend to separate at a high rotating speed. In this paper, loss of contact is represented by a zero contact load and a negative contact deformation, namely clearance. Figure 15 shows the predicted forces applied on the tappet–pushrod interface during one working cycle. The spring force is the sum of the static force plus a dynamic component. The inertial force is generated by the acceleration and mass of all the moving components except the tappet. The spring force is influenced not only by the cam profile and valve spring stiffness, but also by the cam shaft speed because its dynamic component will fluctuate greatly at a high rotating speed. The inertial force depends on the acceleration of the moving components [37]. The oscillation of the inertial force in Fig. 16 is mainly induced by the elasticity of the transmission chain from the bottom of the pushrod to the valve head. The possibility of the loss of contact depends on the magnitudes of the spring force and the inertial force. A series of impacts and subsequent rebounds of the pushrod upon the tappet are found. It is also seen that the surge behaviour of the valve spring subsists over the cam working action at high speed, even if the valve has closed. The spring surge could not only cause contact separation between two neighbouring components and subsequent rebound with impact-induced implications, but could also cause valve toss or flutter, which has many associated problems, including wear and fatigue of the usually poorly lubricated valve–valve seat contact and small fluctuations in the combustion pressure [17].

caption.p: Mechanism of the loss of the tappet–pushrod contact
Contact condition of the rocker arm

sec.p: Although the tappet lost contact with the pushrod at a cam angle of about 60° and 75°, as shown in Fig. 15, the pushrod–rocker arm and rocker arm–valve contacts are not lost evidently at the same cam position, see the contact deformation and contact force in Fig. 16 (P–A represents the pushrod–rocker arm contact and A–V represents the rocker arm–valve contact). One reason for the loss of the tappet–pushrod contact is a short duration. Another important reason is that the spring load is still an effective constrained force for the valve. Therefore, the pushrod, rocker arm, and valve is still a whole system.

Figure 17 shows a comparison between the valve lift at 2150 r/min and that provided by another lumped rigid mass system model neglecting the elasticity in the valve-train system. In the valve opening period, the valve lift is smaller than that provided by the lumped rigid mass model. This is called the sinking of the valve-train system, and it is induced by the combined effect of the elasticity of the valve-train system and the high negative inertial force at high speed (in Fig. 15). This is also a process in which the energy is stored in the valve-train system in the form of elastic strain. The energy will be released gradually and will then lead to valve jump behaviour. This jump behaviour is called pseudo jump in order to differentiate that induced by the separation of components in a valve-train system [1]. A valve bounce was predicted by the flexible coupled valve-train dynamics model at the valve closing period, and this behaviour was not predicted by the lumped rigid mass model.

The inertial force of the tappet is not included in the study of the transmission chain in Fig. 15 because it is found that the loss of the tappet–pushrod contact is much more likely to occur than that for the cam–tappet contact. This behaviour can be explained by the fact that the tappet also has a friction constraint from tappet bore. The friction losses of the cam–tappet–bore contact represent about 85 to 90 per cent of the total friction losses in the valve train [38]. Therefore, it is necessary to show the characteristics in the cam–tappet contact (see Fig. 18). The cam profile of the subject valve train is type FB2, with a ramp of constant acceleration–constant velocity type. The curve of the lubricant film thickness is similar to the cam profile in acceleration. The thickness of the lubricant film is entirely over 0.1
μ
m at the opening ramp part and the closing ramp part. There are two conspicuous periods in which the lubricant is especially sufficient and has a maximum thickness of about 0.6 μm: one is from 34.4° to 53.9°, and the other is from 136.7° to 156.4°, respectively, corresponding to the two phases of positive valve acceleration. Lubricant conditions are likely to be less severe in the two periods, with a predominant hydrodynamic regime of lubrication, due to increased lubricant film thickness.

The cam nose location corresponds to the cam angle of 95.5°. The lubricant film thickness reduces to the bottom between the two conspicuous periods, prior to and after the cam nose contact with the tappet. The reversal of the oil entraining velocity is responsible for the thin film thickness [16, 17, 20, 21]. As can be seen from Fig. 18, the friction force mostly concentrates on this period since a thin film thickness exists. In this case, non-Newtonian behaviour of the oil prevails in the contact zone, and the viscous friction force contributes most to the total friction force between the cam and the tappet. On the other hand, the oscillation frequency of the friction force is the same as that of the dynamic system (see the pushrod force in Fig. 10). This also validates the viewpoint by Teodorescu et al. [37] that the oscillatory behaviour of the contact force, often misunderstood as repetitive impacts, is in fact merely owing to the cumulative effect of system compliance.

The interaction between the cam and tappet is one of the sources leading to vibration and noise. The contact force can be directly transmitted to cam shaft bearings via the cam shaft, and then excites the vibration of the engine body. A Cartesian diagram of the forces loading the cam shaft bearing in the case of 900 r/min is shown in Fig. 19. It is assumed that each bearing supports one half of the forces loading the neighbouring cam. The entire cam working cycle can be divided into two parts, prior to and after the cam nose contact with the tappet, the rise course, and the fall course. The strain energy is stored in the valve spring, pushrod, rocker arm, and other elastic components in the rise course, and is released in the fall course. The two courses are all accompanied by the vibration of the elastic components. As shown in Fig. 19, the composite loading force on the cam shaft bearing has a strong oscillation, and has almost the same direction between the two steep changes. This is a typical source that can excite structure vibration. Figure 20 shows the cam shaft bearing load for the case of 1300 r/min. The loaded condition becomes worse with an increase of cam shaft speed. Without the protective effect of a lubrication film formed in the cam shaft bearing, the cam shaft bearing load, together with structure vibration, may cause significant frictional losses, wear, and scuffing of the contact surfaces in extreme cases.

sec.title: 5 Summary
sec.p: A rigid–flexible coupled dynamics model has been developed for the dynamic analysis of an internal combustion engine valve-train system. The rigid–flexible coupled dynamics model takes into account the elastic vibration of all elastic components that work as continuous flexible bodies and the coupling between the elastic vibration and the rigid motion of all components in the valve train. The contact friction in the cam–tappet contact is also taken into consideration based on the elasto-hydrodynamic mechanism. The effectiveness of the rigid–flexible coupled dynamics model was verified by comparison between the predicted and experimental results. The advantages of the rigid–flexible coupled dynamics method were discussed by comparing the predicted results using a rigid–flexible coupled dynamics valve-train model and a lumped rigid mass system valve-train model.

sec.title: Finite-difference scheme
sec.p: In this paper, the dynamic equations are solved by using the finite-difference method. The first derivative is
where h is the step in the time domain or in the spatial domain. Further differentiation yields higher derivatives [25, 26, 31, 32]

The equations of motion can be solved using the finite-difference method by introducing the partial derivative term (46) into equations (11), (13), (16), (30), and (31). This involves dividing the time into a finite number of equal-time intervals and developing a linear difference equation describing the dynamic characteristics of the rigid body. Thus, a solution of the equations (11), (13), (16), (30), and (31) can be obtained as
Assuming a time and space discretization interval and introducing the partial derivative term (46) and (48) into equations (14), (18), (25), and (28) yield a series of expressions
The following relationship between the interval in the time domain and the step in the spatial domain must hold in order to guarantee stability of solutions [3, 26, 30]

sec.title: Boundary-value problems
sec.p: Equations (54) to (57) give the displacements of section j of each elastic body at time t + Δt. First of all, the values of displacements at the boundary must be obtained. The boundary problems of equations (56) and (57) can be overcome by the conditions provided by equations (26) and (29). As for equations (54) and (55), the fictitious displacements of the artificial nodes are not given directly. However, these fictitious displacements can be obtained using the boundary conditions related to the dynamic equations (54) and (55) [26, 31, 32].
The fictitious displacement up + 1(t) in equation (54) can be obtained using the boundary condition (15)
So the fictitious displacement is

There are four displacements of the fictitious nodes: v−1(t), v0(t), vn + 1(t), and vn + 2(t) in equation (55), respectively at −1, 0, n+1, and n+2, see Fig. 21. They can be obtained using the boundary conditions of the moments and transversal forces on the left and right ends of the rocker arm. Equations (19) can be written in the following form

caption.p: Schematic of the flexible rocker arm

sec.p: Thus, the four fictitious displacements of the artificial nodes can be defined as
The elastic-damping support condition will become a free boundary condition during the separation events

sec.title: Contact parameters between components
sec.p: The values of contact stiffness are obtained from the static contact relationship between the applied force and the displacement using the finite-element method. Figure 21 shows the contact model of pushrod valve adjuster and coloured results of contact displacements. The contact analyses of other parts are similar to the example shown in Fig. 22.

caption.p: Contact model between pushrod and valve adjuster

sec.p: The values of the contact damping coefficients are assumed to be 3 to 5 per cent of the critical damping first, and then adjusted based on the comparison between experiment and simulation [39, 40]
Ccontact is the contact damping, Kcontact is the contact stiffness, m1 and m2 are the masses of the two components in contact, and ζ is the damping ratio.

sec.title: Simplification of the rocker arm
sec.p: The deformation of the rocker arm is considered to be very small. It is linear since the linear elastic material properties with a Young modulus and density are assumed. So the rocker arm can be reduced to a simply supported beam where the moment of inertia, bending modulus, and area of cross-section are constant (see Fig. 23(b)). A force and a moment, denoted as PT and MT, are applied to the right end of the rocker arm and its reduced system. The moment of inertia and bending modulus of the cross-section can be obtained using

caption.p: Simplification schematic of the rocker arm: (a) the finite-element model of the rocker arm, and (b) the simply supported beam model of the rocker arm

sec.p: where f is the maximum deflection, σmax is the maximum normal stress, f and σmax are calculated using the finite-element method (see Fig. 23(a)). Assuming a rectangular cross-section, the area of the cross-section can be written as
